user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_GenericClose_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_GenericClose_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    int                             result;
    OS_impl_file_internal_record_t *impl;

    impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_filehandle_table, *token);

    result = close(impl->fd);
    if (result < 0)
    {
        /*
         * close() can technically fail for various reasons, but
         * there isn't much recourse if this call fails.  Just log
         * the failure for debugging.
         *
         * POSIX also does not specify the state of the filehandle
         * after a close() with an error.
         *
         * At least in  Linux/glibc the filehandle is always closed
         * in the kernel and should not be used again or re-closed.
         */
        OS_DEBUG("close: %s\n", strerror(errno));
    }
    impl->fd = -1;
    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_GenericClose_Impl:
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
extern OS_impl_file_internal_record_t OS_impl_filehandle_table[OS_MAX_NUM_OPEN_FILES]
...
static inline osal_index_t OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    return token->obj_idx;
}
...
typedef struct
{
    int  fd;
    bool selectable;
} OS_impl_file_internal_record_t
...
#define OS_DEBUG(__VA_ARGS__) 
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: The following fragments were NOT reported as suspicious and therefore do not need further investigation for Rule 8.13: the function parameter declaration 'int32 OS_GenericClose_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token)' — it already points to a const-qualified type; the inline function 'static inline osal_index_t OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(const OS_object_token_t *token)' — it accepts a pointer to const; the use of 'impl->fd = -1;' — the object is intentionally modified so a non-const pointer is required; the call 'result = close(impl->fd);' and the handling of its return value — these do not involve pointer-to-object qualifications. Other code fragments in the snippet either do not involve pointer types or already use const where appropriate, so they are not relevant to Rule 8.13.
